title: Does every champion have to be overflowing with confidence?
body:
Based on their voice lines alone, every single champion thinks they're the strongest fighter in the universe (obviously it's more accentuated with characters like Aurelion Sol, but it's still there on everybody else too). I get that it's an easy way to fulfill player fantasy empowerment but do we really need it? Can we have a few characters that are timid or even scared at times? I think something like that would some nice personality variety to the roster.

PS: After looking through the roster, I think the closest thing we have to a timid character is Nami. She's the only one that seems a little unsure of herself at times. I would include Galio here, but the rework kind of did away with that.

Edit: And then there's Amumu. Well, maybe it says something about character timidness if he's so easily forgettable.

replies.body:
I'm neither an expert on the subject nor do I speak for anyone here when I say this:

I totally and utterly agree. I think deep characters are normally vulnerable and almost always tragic in some way. Look at lead characters from the most popular TV series around and they're almost always deeply flawed. Now, a bunch of league champs _are_ actually pretty 3 dimensional in this way, but their most overt character traits are rarely "sad boi" so I get where you're coming from.

I think one of the most beautifully tragic characters in the game is actually Ivern, if you read his lore and listen to a few of his lines that sort of existential sadness is there, it's just not overt. He comes off as sort of goofy and fun, but that's a bit of the genius of it to me. Some of the deepest, saddest people are those that make us all laugh and have a good time.

I think you raise a valid question. Do people need "I'M A TOTAL BADASS" to feel empowered when they play? I don't know. I'd like to think not. But then again I'm a support main, so, yanno.

I honestly find Sion's strongest quotes to be his introspective ones.  Anyone can be the bloodcurdling monster, but to be confused, maybe even disgusted at what you are but can't stop?

That's tragic. That's Sion.

Yeah I feel the same and in general there are some other champions who have quotes like that.

Jhin for example has some quotes that hint at the fact that Jhin knows that what he does is wrong and that he wants to stop it,but he just can't,cause he is literally addicted to killing,because nothing else gives him joy.And all this talk about art is just his way of justifying his murders to himself.

Then there is Galio,who struggles with his disconnect to the demacians and the fact that he is always destroying the source of his life.

Diana used to be the most deep character in League imo. Her login music and original lore was special. In her login music, you hear her sorrow, her pain, her anger, as her misplaced trust became forged into a cold, unforgiving scorn. Diana had arguably the most compelling lore in the game, especially when considering the amount of depth in such a short passage. Her crusade against the Solari was cruel, and perhaps, morally wrong; but it also, somehow, felt righteous: this is what made her lore so great.

I think you have a point with Poppy, but she seems more unassuming than unsure. Like, she's fairly confident when she's fighting. It seems more like it just never occurred to her that she might be the hammer's choice.

She's confident when fighting because she's a _soldier_.  A soldier is not a hero, they aren't special and are trained to put others before themselves.  So when it comes to being a soldier, Poppy doesn't need confidence, she is assured she is one.

But a hero?  Imo Poppy is in constant denial because she's afraid of being the hero.  How could she be the hero after all?  That would mean she'd be more important than Orlorn, her friend and commander.  

You may not think that makes sense, and you're right it doesn't.  That's the point.  Fear and lack of confidence screw over your logic and make you think things incorrectly.  Poppy will never call herself the hero because she can't see herself as a better person than Orlorn.

I think many of the champions are scared and uncertain. For example, we have {{champion:32}} {{champion:3}} {{champion:99}} {{champion:267}} {{champion:78}} {{champion:163}} {{champion:83}} .

Amumu is constantly unsure and sad as a champion of course. He is cursed to forever to be alone and probably doesn't know why he keeps searching for a friend at times. His story is simple, yet likely the saddest in League. He is depression incarnate, and probably has no real self-confidence at all.

Galio is unsure of what he should do most of the time. Sure, on the outside, he appears to be some big oaf that loves to constantly fight, and he probably is. However, if he kills whatever is causing him to be alive... well, he's no longer alive afterwards. While he would probably never put himself over others, there's probably a small part of him that is unsure if killing every last mage would be the best for himself. Is he doing what is right? When I kill a mage, should I really be killing them?

Lux is unsure of her place in her kingdom and even family. In a nation that taboos magic of most kinds, Lux doesn't really know if what she does is right and where it might lead her in life. In her lore she has come to accept it enough to not want to get rid of it, but she still doesn't know what her powers will do for her in life.

Nami, of course, has the weight of her tribe put upon her. She isn't the oldest and is a little naive, making the weight that much more on her. She's not sure what is right and wrong, or what what is so to speak. She's exploring a world completely foreign to her, making her of course have doubts on if she can support her tribe and perform her duty.

Poppy... Poppy's lack of self-confidence is part of her character. While it could be described as simple naivety and ignorance, Poppy doesn't believe she herself can be a hero despite all signs pointing to it. Poppy has never stopped and believed she herself is worthy of being the hero, simply seeing herself as just the "delivery girl" so to speak for the real hero.

Taliyah has little knowledge of her own powers and isn't really sure if she can control her powers all that well. While she masters it a good bit in her lore, it's still likely that she is far from being where she needs to be. She constantly struggles to feel like she is living up to what she could be and if her powers are really for the best.

Yorick is never hopeful. While he fights on for what he believes is right, Yorick is no optimist. He knows that he might not be able to complete his quest and there is a very high chance he won't. He'll keeping fighting until that day comes, but Yorick has no doubt that he will be tested during his journey and there may be some trials he simply will fail to. The only reason Yorick hasn't given up yet is because he knows that even if he gives up he won't pass on to a peaceful afterlife. It's either carry on or be tortured for eternity, which even the most doubtful person would not want, especially since they themselves had nothing to do with the Black Mist spreading. If Yorick had caused the Black Mist, I could easily see him letting go and offing himself because he feels his past crimes are worthy of a death sentence. However, Yorick didn't cause the Black Mist. He's simply a survivor that HAS to press on. Yorick has no faith in himself, but there is no other choice for him but to press on and continue to fight, even if he wanted to quit.

Plus, I would like to note that while this game obviously has it's share of "doubtful fighters", it's called League of Legends. While a hand full can have some doubt in themselves, you don't typically become a legend by having such a ginormous fault. You become a legend by being someone big and/or doing something big, and that usually involves having to have courage and the ability to believe in yourself. While everyone has faults, the inability to believe in one's self is typically the direct opposite of what a legend of any kind, hero or villain, is.
